title: Thursday, 30th May 2019
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

You know those Sliding Doors moments? ......

Blank canvas good morning all
BE11:08am

The points where fate bisects and continues independently on separate timelines?

BE11:08am

(Welcome to Markets Live, btw. FT Alphaville's whatever with etc.)

Blank canvas we're listening
11:08 am
BE11:09am

Well, here's a Sliding Doors moment.

Soundbuy Hello
BE11:09am

Pearson’s 58-year ownership of the FT Group ended in high drama on Thursday as the Japanese media group Nikkei trumped its rival with an eleventh-hour bid. “It went down to the last 10 minutes,” said one person close to the talks.

Axel Springer, the German media group, had victory in its sights early in the day after a long courtship of the UK-based news group. But it ended up being beaten to the prize by Nikkei, Japan’s largest media company, which only began exploring an offer for the Financial Times five weeks ago.

Led by chief executive Mathias Döpfner, Axel Springer had been in talks with the FT Group since last year about a minority investment in the group. The discussions evolved into outright takeover discussions over the past several weeks, according to people close to the matter.

BE11:09am

https://www.ft.com...-8873-775ba7c2ea3d

11:09 am
BE11:10am

So here we are, on the good timeline, sitting in Bracken House with a revitalised newsroom and a glass cabinet full of awards.

SkippyGoLucky Hey
Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:10am

While on the other timeline, we're worrying about what life will be like under the part ownership of KKR.

BE11:11am

The founding family and chief executive of Germany’s Axel Springer have teamed up with private equity firm KKR in a bid to take the powerful media group private.

Springer confirmed that it was in talks with KKR over a “strategic participation” in a statement late on Wednesday. The offer for the company with a market value of €4.9bn is being orchestrated by Mathias Döpfner, chief executive of Springer, who has been putting a deal together for months, one person familiar with the discussions said.

BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-9935-ad75bb96c849

...... a reminder that after losing out on the FT, Axel bought Business Insider

Snowman morning

And has since been sniffing around every possible deal for classifieds, because investors really seem to hate print.

Snowman anything re FGP much appreciated
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Today's news would seem to be a combination of those two factors.

BE11:13am

First, they can't get a deal away for eBay Germany or whatever without diluting the family. Second, investors don't like them.

Grouchmonkey DeLa Rue debacle?
BE11:13am

Here's UBS.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

This is happening at a time where online classified assets are seeing increased levels of M&A activity, following a move by Blackstone and Hellmann & Friedman to take Scout24 private (18x EBITDA, 26x PE), Apax Partners' take-over of Trade Me in New Zealand (15x EBITDA), SilverLake's acquisition of ZPG (20x EBITDA) and news that eBay could potentially sell its classifieds assets portfolio. We believe private equity may be attracted to online classifieds due to strong revenue growth, good operating leverage and high cash flow conversion, with Axel Springer owning one of the largest online classifieds portfolio in Europe (60% of 2018 group EBITDA, 70% of UBS valuation). With the shares down -9% ytd pre-news, vs the European online sector up ~20%, we estimate Axel Springer online classifieds assets are trading on ~17x FY19 PE, a material discount to Rightmove (29x), Autotrader (27x) and Scout24 (25x), which we believe is unjustified despite Axel Springer's less favourable asset mix. Yesterday’s announcement further reinforces our view that the value of Axel Springer’s online classifieds assets is low relative to peers and private side valuation references. We remain Buyers of Axel Springer.

Snowman DLAR, can a govt locked in Brexit really give away the passport contract to a french/Dutch consort.... !
BE11:14am

Ditto JP Morgan.

Soundbuy Close to the company song being a German ditty.........narrow escape
BE11:15am

The Online Classifieds space has been in focus with regards to M&A
in recent months and we highlighted upside potential for Axel in our
recent upgrade note [...]. We argued that the shares are too cheap for the company’s growth profile trading on 9x 2019E EV/EBITDA for a +12% 19E-21E EBITDA CAGR. The company’s assets are structurally growing and Springer will continue to pursue its growth strategy – in this context, KKR may bring additional execution and Springer may also take part in further M&A consolidation in the Online Classifieds space (~65% of Springer’s EBITDA), a sector that has been in focus in recent months with a high degree of M&A activity (Scout/Schibsted/Adevinta).

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Our feedback from several roadshows (and management’s
presentation at the recent JPM TMT CEO conference in London
last week) has been that management has been (rightly so, in our view)
frustrated with the company’s low valuation versus peers despite a
strong EBITDA growth profile, which is in our view driven by
overstated concerns around the company’s exposure to (a declining)
Print business (which in fact is only ~15% of EBITDA).

BE11:16am

And some stretch valuation stuff from Barclays.

BE11:16am

We show below our SOTP valuation for Axel Springer, which drives our price target of €57.30, 27% upside to last night’s closing price. We use a 5x EBITDA multiple (applied to 2020 EBITDA) for News Media excluding Business Insider; a value of €600m for BI; a multiple of 8x EBITDA for the non-classifieds online businesses in Marketing Media and 11.6x EBITDA for Classifieds. And we include a 10.8x EBITDA multiple on corporate costs (average of the other multiples) and include a positive €60m for other small stakes and a negative €150m for pension.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Business Insider gets a E600m valuation in the basic Barclays SOTP based on ebitda of .... E2m.

BE11:18am

Which feels a tad punchy for a volume shop? Maybe? I dunno. Here's the stretch stuff.

BE11:18am

We assume an extra €100m for Business Insider (€700m) and we use for the classifieds a 25% discount to the average multiple of Rightmove, Autotrader and Scout24 (given that on average Axel’s classifieds businesses have less strong market positions). But to stick to our consistent approach for the last few years, we compare them based on EV/NOPAT and then “convert” this to EV/EBITDA. This is because on average those three peers have a lower tax rate and lower capex as a % of sales than Axel Springer.

So the average 2019 EV/NOPAT multiple for those three peers is 28.9x (they are all basically the same: Auto Trader 28.5x; Rightmove 29.1x; Scout24: 29.0x). A 20% discount is 21.7x. And based on the appropriate depreciation and tax rate for Axel’s classifieds, that implies a target EV/EBITDA of 12.4x.

Putting that into our SOTP for Classifieds Media (and including the extra €100m for BI) implies a potential value per share (one year forward) of €61.35 or 36% upside.

 Implications — Although the strong underlying results are marred by significant provision charges, we expect the shares to react positively to the prospect of a group restructuring which may unlock some value from the US operations.

Let's try Canaccord instead.

BE11:29am

We welcome the decision by the Board to create a more focused portfolio, largely centered around the North American First Student and First Transit contracting businesses. Existing UK Rail franchises will continue to be operated in line with contractual terms, but future commitments in the form of new franchises appear unlikely at this stage. The Greyhound business will be sold, and a structural solution is being sought for the separation of First Bus. It will take some time to implement these plans but, over time, we believe that there is significant potential to generate shareholder value.

AMALtd late morning
BE11:29am

Uh, nope. Damien Brewer at RBC maybe?

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Actual change is key: Until prospects of externally led change increased, FGP shares traded as low as 79p in the last year – 7% below the 2013 rights (85p). We find no investors (even large ones who suggest they have been uninvited from today’s presentation) with an appetite to return to a 79p share.

BE11:30am

Okay, that's more like it.

BE11:30am

Key to FGP LN shares are measures that allow escape from its debt and pension ‘value trap’. Today sees:
l FY18 and FY19 one-off charges now larger than the equity raised in the 2013 rights issue.
l Cash outflows to come acknowledged with yet more ‘one’-offs - with another rail impairment of £102.1m. This is much larger than we
expected - but crucially only £65m of it is yet to be drawn (turning into cash outflow from the parent company). This is more in line with our view of cash
outflow risk at SWR. N America sees a £95m insurance-related charge – implying previous profits have been overstated and that insurance costs in
future will be a drag on margins. UK Bus sees a one-off £16m Manchester exit cost excluded from operating profits.
l Perplexing to us, FGP is still bidding for West Coast - despite two value-destroying rail contracts at SWR and TPE. Shareholders need to ask why
this ‘fence sitting’ continues.

Tom Dalgleish decent for the curators

We think the risk under this plan is that the highest multiple potential (Student Bus) operation remains diluted/trapped in a corporate structure exposed to: (1) future non-Student pension cash outflows; and (2) trapped by a question mark over the realisable value on an under-invested UK Bus operation) and, exposed to future rail cash outflow commitments (not visible in the P&L) and the multiple compression this brings.

Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 3,053, down 131 (-4.11%), High: 3,208, Low: 3,020, Volume: 388.84k

Leading us down FTSE wise right now, even though H2 results look okay at the headlines.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Credit Suisse with the lump of summary.

BE11:38am

Johnson Matthey reported H2 18/19 underlying PBT of £272mn, 1% below
our estimates (£274m), and 2% ahead of consensus (£267mn). 2019/20E
guidance for mid-high single digit growth excluding currency (FX impact at spot rates £(2)m at operating profit). Mid-point of guidance implies £606mn adjusted operating profit or £560mn PBT in 2019/20E – in line with consensus £602m/£560m respectively (guidance includes £2mn positive for IFRS16). Divisionally, earnings have beaten consensus in all divisions except New Markets/Elimination where higher costs for eLNO ramp up/legal costs weighed on profits. JMAT has announced the construction of 3 eLNO customer test centres in UK/Japan in 2019/20 and remain on track to deliver the first commercial 10,000 tonne facility in 2021 (potential to scale to to 100,000 tonnes).

luzh If you're taking requests, any opinion on Halfords? Always liked their stores, but share price performance seems... terrible?

New Markets is the batteries stuff, which printed a £1m operating loss. Consensus was at £10..4m profit.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Unsurprisingly, costs are the issue here.

BE11:40am

Here's JP Morgan.

Catgotmytongue Any PVH Corp in the US
Tom Dalgleish Reinvented neither itself nor batteries
BE11:41am

Despite the weaker auto demand, Johnson Matthey (JM) has delivered 2H/FY19 (ended Mar '19) broadly in line with consensus with FY adj EBIT/EPS growth of 8%/10% on CC, in line with the upgraded guidance of HSD growth in Nov 2018. The known tailwinds in the Clean Air division (+11% CC sales growth for FY in line with JPMe) from the significant share gain in the EU diesel market and the strong US truck demand combined with significant cost savings, most of which were reinvested for future growth/improvements, helped the company buck the weaker auto volume trend.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The company expects FY20 underlying EBIT growth to be within its M/T target of mid- to high-single digit growth. Given 5% CC EBIT growth in FY2H19 and the ebbing impact from above-mentioned tailwinds and the still soft auto demand, around mid-single digit EBIT growth for FY20 seems more plausible, in our opinion. This is broadly consistent with our current estimate and consensus of ~6% EBIT growth for FY20. Though, interest expenses are guided to be significantly higher vs. previous year and well above (low) consensus which based on our back-of the envelope calculations implies ~3% potential cut to FY20 EPS consensus FY20 capex guidance of up to £500m vs £323m in FY19 is also much higher than JPMe of £390m and consensus of £370m. This will likely result in a significant cut to FCF consensus estimates (and associated significant increase in net debt estimates) and might raise some concerns that the investments needed to deliver the target earnings growth might be materially higher than that reflected in current consensus.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Wall of text from Citi to summarise.

BE11:48am

Citi's Take — EPS were 1c above guidance as revs were essentially in line, though GM missed cons by ~60bps (SG&A came in better). U.S. retail (factory stores) was especially weak, with comps down 4-5% at TH and CK, and down 6% in Heritage. Comps slowed in all brands, all regions with TH NAm, putting up its first negative comp since 1Q17, while CK Int’l saw their first negative comp since 1Q16. And both brands are expected to slow further in 2Q with mgmt noting weakness in the U.S. and China in 2Q. 2Q guidance is well below consensus and F19 guidance is 2H weighted, and implies an EPS increase of ~17% in 2H vs an EPS decline of 4% in 1H.
 The Qtr: EPS of $2.46 vs our $2.42E, consensus of $2.45, and guidance of $2.40-2.45. Sales +1.8% (+6.0% constant Fx) and adj op margin +50bps, incl GM -70bps and SG&A leverage of 120bps. Tommy +9% (vs guidance of +10%), CK +4% (vs guidance +5%), and Heritage +1% (vs guidance +1%). Total inventory +6% vs 1Q guidance of sales +2% (cc).
 Guidance: Reduced F19 non-GAAP EPS guidance from $10.30-10.40 to $10.20-10.30 (vs cons $10.43), as Fx is now expected to negatively impact results by an incremental $0.10. However, the company also reduced its interest expense expectation for the year, which added ~$0.09, meaning it lowered the core business (ex fx) by about that amt. Guidance based on cc sales +5% (vs +5% prev), including Tommy +9% cc (vs +8% prev), Calvin +2% cc (vs +3% prev), and Heritage flat (vs +3% prev). 2Q19 non-GAAP EPS guidance of $1.85-1.90 vs cons of $2.42, based on sales flat (vs cons +3%). In constant Fx, mgmt guided 2Q revs +2% (vs +6% in 1Q) with TH revs +6% (vs +9% in 1Q) and CK down 2% (vs +4% in 1Q).

Soundbuy Canada Goose - just goggled.........a grand for a parka...........zzzzzz

Much of the sellside saying it remains a turnaround story and the miss is largely FX

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Such as this from CL King .......

BE11:50am

At a high level, Calvin Klein (CK) and Tommy Hilfiger (TH) are largely
performing in line with their respective annual plans. Incremental fundamental
weakness emanates more from the Heritage Brands, but from an earnings
perspective is wholly offset by lower interest expense associated with the recent
debt refi. Geographically, retail is tougher in the U.S. and China, although
Europe continues to exhibit strength. Given conservative buying patterns from
retailers throughout the industry domestically, inventory at retail remains
relatively clean (despite a slower pace of industry sales, given unfavorable
spring weather). Domestic tourist locations were also noted as being challenged.

Grouchmonkey England hundred up for 1 wicket. DeLa Rue?
BE11:51am

The stock traded down ~10% in post-market trading, a notable decline
considering a cumulative sell-off of 30%+ in the last month alone. We stipulate that multiple global events, including the burgeoning tariff conflict with China, botched Brexit and sundry domestic challenges, have reduced the number of safe havens for predictable growth in the past few months. However, this management team has not lowered annual non-GAAP EPS guidance in 19 consecutive fiscal quarters (and we are not including the Q1 print, as foreign exchange variations account for the entirety of this period’s adjustment). And then there are the current valuation metrics, which are not only well below the median, but (save for the 2008 recession) are also below the previous bottom end of the range. Again, the newspaper headlines are less than ideal and Mother Nature is certainly not helping, with unseasonably cool temperatures extending deep into spring. Nevertheless, with history as a guide, management’s execution track record, juxtaposed with historically low valuation metrics, limits near-term downside risk and keeps us highly constructive on the name.

BE11:57am

And I note it for several reasons. First, Moran Stanley's cut forecasts.

Soundbuy @Flaneur - noted.............
BE11:57am

Weaker passenger fares and capacity oversupply not fully offset by cost savings result in trimming RYA NI by -12.0% for FY20 and easyJet PBT by -11.3% for FY19. Ryanair guided passenger fares to be in the range of -2% to +1% for FY20e, and easyJet now guides 2H19 revenue per seat performance to be slightly down YoY. Both Ryanair and Easyjet echoed that the passenger fare story into summer remains cautious, even though there is some tapering of capacity in winter.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

Morgan, even.

BE11:58am

Ryanair noted that the weak macro environment is affecting fares in the UK, while oversupply of capacity is affecting other European markets, like Germany and Austria. easyJet has a similar story, as ~33% of its capacity is exposed to the UK, and it also has material exposure to other competitive markets. Both are banking on better cost performance; however, Ryanair has been impacted by the grounding of the Boeing Max aircraft. EasyJet expects its cost performance to come out slightly better for the year, as so far it has seen ~30% reduction in disruption costs and has continued cost savings initiatives. Ryanair has guided for an increase in FY20e unit costs by 2%, due to a combination of MAX delay, Laudamotion cost integration (weighted to 1H20) and GBP headwinds.

JimboRock TA
Grouchmonkey @Tom well, last year roasting hot weather, England get a good run in World Cup wet sales up and.....the market marked the pub cos down on the basis they should have made more. This year, the cold drizzle seems to have actually supported the share price of GMK, Marstons, Fullers and Youngs. go figure.
BE11:58am

We believe RYA's cost guidance may be conservative, but with lack of visibility on the MAX return to service, the guidance seems prudent. Both companies will continue to pursue market share gains.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

Ryanair has been fairly vocal about growing faster in a weaker environment, and easyJet's capacity in 2H19 has continued to grow at 7% (FY19 growth of 10%). Ryanair management commented that the company will continue to grow faster in order to gain market share, even if this is not profitable in the short term. We lower our easyJet price target to £1,050p (from £1,150p); our price target for Ryanair moves from €11.50 to €10.50. Maintain Equal weight. Our reduction in PT is mainly driven by lower earnings forecasts, as Ryanair's NI reduces by -12.0% to €859m in FY20 and by -9.3% to €1,074m in FY21.

BE11:59am

Similarly, PBT for easyJet reduces by -11.3% to £412m in FY19 and by -10.2% to £498m in FY20. Our price targets now sit very close to the EV/NAV multiple for both the airlines, with easyJet at 0.85x and Ryanair at 1.1x. We acknowledge the share price weakness may seem a reasonable entry point, given limited downside for both airlines, based on their historical troughs. However, in the short term, we think this is balanced by the risk of a continued lower fares environment and macro uncertainty resulting in further rebasing risk to FY19/20 earnings levels.

Excel Developer @red: actually, most of the time, I skimp and listen on Radio 5 live. Just as exciting.
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Here are some of SG's cribnotes.

BE12:01pm

The softening macro environment is burdening demand in Italy and Germany, while in the UK, Brexit uncertainty is not helping either. However, due to limited supply, late bookings might still come in at good yields. The group has still to generate c.GBP1.5bn in sales in summer, so there is still a significant revenue opportunity (but also a risk). EasyJet already operates under a post-Brexit setup, i.e. it has a UK and a EU airline, with all aircraft flying EU domestic routes registered in the EU. Including the stake of founder Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the company’s EU ownership stands at some 49.6%, i.e. very close to the 50% level needed to comply with EU ownership requirements. EZJ would have preferred a Brexit in March, as it would have provided clarity.

Excel Developer Korean won has weakened of late. I might be a Korean tv.
BE12:02pm

With regards to financing, EasyJet is going through a period of heavy capital expenditure and is planning to raise money via a bond issue. Based on its current BBB rating, it paid only a 1.125% coupon in its last bond offering, and it expects to obtain similar conditions for an upcoming bond. EZJ is not interested in long-haul flights, the CEE region or Scandinavia. Nor is it interested in taking over any Thomas Cook assets.
